00:00.quote: It was now midnight, and my task was drawing to a close.
00:00.title: Frankenstein
00:00.author: Mary Shelley

09:00.quote: At nine o'clock in the morning we started for the scene of the tragedy.
09:00.title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes
09:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

10:30.quote: At half-past ten the fly arrived, and we set off.
10:30.title: Dracula
10:30.author: Bram Stoker

12:00.quote: It was already noon when I awoke, and I felt that I had no time to lose.
12:00.title: Pride and Prejudice
12:00.author: Jane Austen

14:15.quote: At a quarter past two, I was awakened by a soft tap at the door.
14:15.title: Jane Eyre
14:15.author: Charlotte Brontë

15:00.quote: The clock struck three o'clock, and I heard him walk to the door.
15:00.title: Wuthering Heights
15:00.author: Emily Brontë

16:00.quote: At four o'clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-maker to make his appearance.
16:00.title: Emma
16:00.author: Jane Austen

17:30.quote: At half past five we were all assembled in the drawing-room.
17:30.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
17:30.author: Oscar Wilde

18:00.quote: It was six o'clock when they reached the lodge, and the sun was setting.
18:00.title: A Tale of Two Cities
18:00.author: Charles Dickens

19:00.quote: At seven o'clock the coffee was made and the pan was on the back of the stove hot and ready to cook the chops.
19:00.title: Moby Dick
19:00.author: Herman Melville

20:00.quote: The clock struck eight, and still the old man did not appear.
20:00.title: Great Expectations
20:00.author: Charles Dickens

21:00.quote: At nine o'clock that evening I found myself in the sitting-room at Baker Street.
21:00.title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes
21:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

22:00.quote: It was ten o'clock at night before we found a suitable opportunity.
22:00.title: Frankenstein
22:00.author: Mary Shelley

23:00.quote: At eleven o'clock this night the whole city will be asleep.
23:00.title: The Count of Monte Cristo
23:00.author: Alexandre Dumas
